section-block.rac_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: By Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell
section-block.rac_book_summary: My Body tells all about the different parts of your body, including how you breathe and how you sense things. You will find out about the inside and outside of your body, how it grows, and how it stays healthy with this informative book!

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about parts of their bodies. Encourage different students to name parts they know, such as their arms, legs, and head.
Invite children to sing “If You’re Happy and You Know It.” Include directions with body parts, such as “stomp your feet,” “nod your head,” and “clap your hands.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read My Body, written by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell.
Scout loves to read informational books that help us learn about ourselves. Scout learns lots of fun facts!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What body parts help us move?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompt.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s name some of the body parts that are inside and outside of our bodies.
How do you think our hair and our skin protect us?
Look at the objects on page 11. How many can you name?
Point to your eye. Each eye sends messages about what you see.
Look at all the foods on these pages. Do you like to eat food from all of the groups? What are your favorite foods?
Look at how much we grow from the time we are babies.
Let’s pretend we are tiny children. Let’s make ourselves as small as we can.
Then we’ll pretend to grow. We’ll stand and make ourselves as tall as we can.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What body parts help us move?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can move with our legs.
We can move with our arms

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about how our bodies work and stay healthy.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do our legs help us walk or fly?
How do our brains help us move?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children’s language skills and knowledge develop, having regular interactions with adults who support them helps. These adults can encourage growth by communicating with children about what they are interested in. Conversations should give children the opportunity to hear and use more sophisticated language.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Follow Rules and Routines
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss some of the rules and routines you have in the classroom, such as gathering together at Circle Time, listening when the teacher speaks, and taking turns doing classroom jobs. Talk with children about the importance of following rules and routines. One rule you might reinforce is to treat classroom materials carefully. (MB)

section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the My Body book cover.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use the Follow Rules and Routines Mind Builder as we revisit the book My Body, written by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell.
Clifford loves the routine of listening and not talking when the teacher reads a book!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look for the Mind Builder follow rules and routines as we reread and talk about some pages of the story.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: These pages show hair and skin. What rules and routines do we have for keeping our hair and skin clean? (MB)
Our brains are in charge of our bodies. They tell the different parts of our bodies to let them know what to do.
This page shows what happens when we exercise. What rules and routines do we have at our school for exercising? (MB)
This page shows many of the things that should be in our routines. That includes eating healthy food, getting enough sleep, drinking enough water, and exercising. What routines do you have? (MB)
These pages show what happens when our bodies get sick or hurt. What routines do we have so that we don’t get sick?
It’s important to communicate with others and tell them how we feel or what we need when we’re not feeling great.
Can you describe a time when you had to tell an adult you didn’t feel well?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to listen to directions and follow rules as they play a game of Simon Says. Model play by starting as Simon and asking children to touch different body parts (e.g., Simon Says touch your knees). Make sure children understand that they should not follow directions if you don’t say “Simon Says.” To reinforce children’s ability to assume different roles in the classroom, have them take turns giving directions as Simon.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the parts of their bodies.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Following routines helps children feel comfortable and secure in the classroom so they can learn. When children follow rules that are part of routines (e.g., washing hands at bathroom time), they are developing important habits that they will take out of the classroom. (Vanderbilt University, 2007)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about using background knowledge to better understand what they are reading. Point out to children that they already know a lot about their own body parts. Have children volunteer some of what they know.Share BK Strategy Card.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book My Body, written by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell.
Scout is excited to read the book and build on what he already knows about bodies!
This is the question I want you to think about as we read today:

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick students to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You might know something about hair already, but did you know that it keeps you warm? What color is your hair? Is it long or short?
What do you know about your brain? Let’s all be quiet for a moment. Even when things are quiet, the brain receives messages.
You might have known ears help you hear, but did you know that they help you balance? When do you need to balance?
What do you already know about food? How does this page help you understand what happens to food in your body?
The glossary shows words you might not have heard before. It tells you what each word means.
Did you use what you already knew about your body as we read the book today? Let’s see how you build on what you already know as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: It sends messages so that you move.

section.rac_body-text: Work together with children to write about the parts of our bodies and what they do, inviting children to use challenging words.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does your brain send so that you can move?
Your brain sends m________ (messages) so that you can move.
Your brain sends messages so that you can move.
What messages does your brain receive from your nose?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children speak in class, expand on what they say. Connect with children by rephrasing their words while adding some new vocabulary. You can also help build on their statements by summarizing what they said or by connecting to their background knowledge. Invite children to continue the conversation.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they have learned this week about their bodies. Review different body parts, and talk about how to stay healthy.
Sing and act out “Open, Shut Them.” Lyrics: Open, shut them (repeat) Give a little clap, clap, clap.Open, shut them. (repeat) Place them in your lap, lap, lap.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes.” We can read the song’s words on a poster.
Scout loves to look at posters with songs. Scout is ready to sing!
The book My Body and the song “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes” focus on parts of our bodies. Let’s see if we can find other connections.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the My Body book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Idea
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Tell children that, along with singing the song, you are going to discuss the poster. Use the prompts below.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the child’s shoulders? What do our shoulders help us do?
Who can point to the child’s knees and toes?
What do knees and toes help us do?
Who can point to the child’s head?
Where are the child’s eyes and ears? What makes the eyes and ears important?
Who can point to the child’s mouth and nose? What makes the mouth and the nose special? What did you find out in My Body?

section.rac_body-text: Have children sing and act out “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes.” Let them sing slowly at first, then speed up each time they repeat the verse.
Provide a writing prompt about our bodies and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt. For example, which parts of your body do you use when you eat a snack?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Singing and moving to songs like “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes” is more than just fun for children. It helps children develop coordination as they follow the actions in time to the music. They also develop language and memory skills, as they repeat the lyrics. Children also become more aware of rhythm, rhyme, and melody as they enjoy the song.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to show and describe how they use different body parts as they eat breakfast, brush their teeth, get to school, sit down, and think about their day.
Sing to “Are You Sleeping?” “Here’s my head. Here’s my nose. See my hands. Touch my toes. Reach up with my fingers, high as they can go. Wave them back, to and fro.”
Introduce a new word that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell the book My Body by Andrea Pinnington and Penny Lamprell.
Scout can’t wait to reread this book! This is informational text. Informational means it tells about real things. It tells facts and Scout loves facts!
This week we read all about our bodies. As we ready the book again, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What body parts are under your skin?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to activity participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl is stretching her arms high, so you can see different body parts. Can you stretch your arms high? Then try naming what’s on the drawing of parts under our skin.
Your brain sends and receives messages to and from your body.
What body part does the picture show? Can you breathe in and fill up your lungs? Then breathe out slowly. What happens to your chest?
The picture shows the girl’s heart. Put your hand over your chest. Do you feel your heart beat? Now run in place and try again.
Do you remember how food gives you energy?
What food makes you feel strong?
The pictures show what you need to stay healthy. Who can tell me what the children on this page are doing?

rac_body-text.rac_body-text: Invite children to Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question: .

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What body parts are under your skin?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: My heart is under my skin.
My bones are under my skin.
My brain is under my skin.
My lungs are under my skin.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw and write about the parts of our bodies and what they do.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is your brain under your skin or over your skin?
My br________ (brain) is under my skin.
My brain is under my skin.
What other body parts are under your skin?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Students who speak languages other than English can build their English skills during Story Time. Help by reading with expression and having children use their bodies to act things out. Point out pictures and ask questions about the illustrations and the text. Repeating key information will help children remember new words.
